Base:Descriptions.Base:Description: white leather booklet on Cesarean Operations
A white leather booklet on Cesarean Operations. It is fairly small and the cover carries the title.
A white leather booklet on Cesarean Operations.
The title of the white leather book, "Cesarean Operations: A Brief History" writ in black calligraphy.
white leather booklet cover
A white leather booklet cover inscribed with the title.
The title of the white leather booklet, "Cesarean Operations: A Brief History" writ in black calligraphy. Just underneath is a small notation that reads, "Written by Cosmo Esposito."
page 1

Since ancient times, cesearean operations have been part of our culture. While there are many tales of cesarean operations resulting in live mothers and live offspring, these operations are risky at best and should not be chanced except for in two cases: first, to save the infant when the mother has died, and second, to seperate the deceased infant and mother so they may be buried seperately, as is decreed proper by the Church.

Since ancient times, cesearean operations have been part of our culture. While there are many tales of cesarean operations resulting in live mothers and live offspring, these operations are risky at best and should not be chanced except for in two cases: first, to save the infant when the mother has died, and second, to seperate the deceased infant and mother so they may be buried seperately, as is decreed proper by the Church.
page 2

The history of cesarean operations is shrouded in myth, and the exact history is unknown.
The word 'cesearan' comes from the Old verb "caedare," to cut. Infants born in a postmortem cesarean operation are called caesones.

The history of cesarean operations is shrouded in myth, and the exact history is unknown.
The word 'cesearan' comes from the Old verb "caedare," to cut. Infants born in a postmortem cesarean operation are called caesones.
page 3

Stories have come down from the generations of heroic efforts to save the mother's life by performing a cesearan operation to remove a stuck or still-born infant, but none of these can be confirmed. The recorded operations, and thus the ones that could be confirmed, were only as a last resort to, as stated before, save the infant from a dead mother or seperate the two for burial. There have, however, been a few confirmable records of operations that ended with a live mother and a live infant, but in these cases, she lived only because of her strength and faith in the Light's blessing.
One such case is that of the Lady Adeline d'Avoirdupois, who in 747 Apres le Miracle, after several days of labour and help from ten midwives, was unable to deliver the children within her. Desperate, her doctor performed a cesearan operation, and the dear Lady gave birth via cesaeran operation twin boys. The names of these infants are not recorded and so unknown, but the fair Lady did continue on until her death in 763 Apres le Miracle, giving birth naturally to six other children, including the famous war lord and knight, Sir Michel d'Avoirdupois, who did lead the armies of the House to protect their lands against the oncoming Doloreaux.

Stories have come down from the generations of heroic efforts to save the mother's life by performing a cesearan operation to remove a stuck or still-born infant, but none of these can be confirmed. The recorded operations, and thus the ones that could be confirmed, were only as a last resort to, as stated before, save the infant from a dead mother or seperate the two for burial. There have, however, been a few confirmable records of operations that ended with a live mother and a live infant, but in these cases, she lived only because of her strength and faith in the Light's blessing.
One such case is that of the Lady Adeline d'Avoirdupois, who in 747 Apres le Miracle, after several days of labour and help from ten midwives, was unable to deliver the children within her. Desperate, her doctor performed a cesearan operation, and the dear Lady gave birth via cesaeran operation twin boys. The names of these infants are not recorded and so unknown, but the fair Lady did continue on until her death in 763 Apres le Miracle, giving birth naturally to six other children, including the famous war lord and knight, Sir Michel d'Avoirdupois, who did lead the armies of the House to protect their lands against the oncoming Doloreaux.
page 4

Many of the early cesarean operations took place in remote areas where medical aid and facilities were lacking. In the absence of such medical professionals, these operations were carried out without consultation with a doctor, often upon a kitchen table or bed. These operations were, because of lack of medical consultation, sometimes carried out earlier in the failed labour when the mother was not near death and the infant not yet terribly distressed, and so success may have been more common in the country, away from hospitals where disease often spread between patients and infections were common because of the unwashed hands of medical attendants. These factors may help to explain such successes as Jacob Nufer's.

Many of the early cesarean operations took place in remote areas where medical aid and facilities were lacking. In the absence of such medical professionals, these operations were carried out without consultation with a doctor, often upon a kitchen table or bed. These operations were, because of lack of medical consultation, sometimes carried out earlier in the failed labour when the mother was not near death and the infant not yet terribly distressed, and so success may have been more common in the country, away from hospitals where disease often spread between patients and infections were common because of the unwashed hands of medical attendants. These factors may help to explain such successes as Jacob Nufer's.
page 5

Nufer was born in 782 and by fact of his work in animal husbandry, also had a knowledge of anatomy. Before performing any operation, he sought to understand the organs and tissues involved, something rarely done during his time. He was at the prime of his career in 805, during which time he wrote several books with detailed illustrations of anatomy. Others soon followed in his footsteps, and many such books were made available over the next decade. These books were, of course, only available to men. Midwives were rarely able to perform cesarean operations properly, and so these operations continued to be only a last result, as it is today, though cesarean operations that are performed in these modern days are much more successful.

the spine of a white leather booklet
The spine of a white leather booklet.

Core:Properties.Core:Property: X[M] \$delay(2, TRUE, "030f"); EmitTo( \$actor, "The pamphlet does not react to you in any way except to look more daunting and self-assured in its knowledge.");
